moves.9. Qc2 b6 10. b4 Na6 11. a3: I plan on a Queen-side attack.
moves.11... Ng4 12. h3 Nf6 13. Bg5 h6 14. Be3: After some minor maneuvering, I'm ready to begin.
moves.19... Nxc5 20. Qxc5: ...to swap down. Now my Queen is well positioned to dominate the board.
moves.21... a6 22. Ba4: I refuse to move off this nice diagonal.
moves.25... Rxb1 26. Rxb1: Now I have full control of the only fully open file.
moves.27... cxd6 28. Nd2: Black's B is hamstrung by his own central pawns.
moves.28... Bg5 29. Nc4: I proceed to attack the weak black pawns.
moves.30... Rc8 31. Nxd6: I win a pawn, and my strategy at last yields a material advantage.
moves.31... Bxd6 32. Rxd6: Black seeks a pure Rook endgame. When behind by a pawn this kind of endgame can often be held.
moves.32... Ra8 33. f3: I lock up my K-side pawns in preparation for my King entering the fray.
moves.34... g5 35. Rc6: Now the Rook is protected if Black's King hastens to the action.
moves.35... Kf8 36. Ke3: Continuing to head for the main theater of action.
moves.37... a5 38. Rc5: I want to keep the Black rook tied to defending the QRP.
moves.38... f6 39. Kc4: My plan is to win the QRP and utilize my 2 passed Q-side Pawns.
moves.39... Kd7 40. Rb5: I'll need to maneuver my King so as to be able to attack the RP with K and R.
moves.43... Rb6+ 44. Rb5: If Black exchanges, the RP falls.
moves.44... Ra6 45. Ra5: I continue to press the issue of the RP.
moves.45... Rxa5 46. Kxa5: Black gives in. This exchange seals things.
moves.46... f5 47. Kxa4: Now I have to clear a path to promotion.
moves.49... Kb7 50. d6: Which one will I try to force through?
moves.50... fxe4 51. fxe4: Black resigns, as he has no way to stop both Q-side passed pawns.

opening: King's Indian (E93), Petrosian system, main line
